questions.question: Descriptive analytics answers the question:

options.B: What happened?

questions.explanation: Descriptive analytics summarizes historical data to answer 'what happened?' It includes reports, dashboards, and data visualization that describe past performance and trends.
questions.tip: Descriptive: What happened? Diagnostic: Why? Predictive: What will happen? Prescriptive: What should we do?

questions.question: For the data set {10, 12, 12, 14, 15, 18, 25}, the median is:
questions.explanation: The median is the middle value when data is ordered. With 7 values, the median is the 4th value = 14. (For even number of values, average the two middle values.)
questions.tip: Median = middle value (50th percentile). More robust than mean for skewed data. Mode = most frequent value.

questions.question: To show the composition of sales by product category as part of a whole, the best chart type is:

options.B: Scatter plot
options.C: Pie chart or stacked bar chart

questions.explanation: Pie charts and stacked bar charts effectively show parts of a whole (composition). Line charts show trends over time, scatter plots show relationships, and histograms show frequency distributions.
questions.tip: Composition: Pie/stacked bar. Trend: Line chart. Relationship: Scatter. Distribution: Histogram. Comparison: Bar chart.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a dimension of data quality?

options.B: Completeness

questions.explanation: Key data quality dimensions include accuracy, completeness, timeliness, consistency, validity, and uniqueness. Complexity is a characteristic of data, not a quality dimension.
questions.tip: Data quality dimensions: Accurate, Complete, Timely, Consistent, Valid, Unique. Poor data quality leads to poor decisions.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of unstructured data?

options.B: Customer emails and social media posts

questions.explanation: Unstructured data lacks a predefined format—examples include emails, documents, videos, and social media. Structured data is organized in databases with defined fields and relationships.
questions.tip: Structured: Databases, spreadsheets (organized). Unstructured: Text, images, video (no predefined format). Semi-structured: JSON, XML.

questions.question: Standard deviation measures:

options.A: The center of a data distribution
options.B: The spread or dispersion of data around the mean

questions.explanation: Standard deviation measures how spread out data values are from the mean. A low standard deviation indicates values are clustered near the mean; high standard deviation indicates wide dispersion.
questions.tip: Standard deviation: Measures dispersion. Higher = more spread. Used with normal distribution (68-95-99.7 rule).

questions.question: In a simple linear regression equation Y = a + bX, the coefficient 'b' represents:

options.B: The change in Y for each unit change in X

questions.explanation: In Y = a + bX, 'b' is the slope—it represents the change in the dependent variable (Y) for each one-unit change in the independent variable (X). 'a' is the Y-intercept.
questions.tip: Slope (b): Change in Y per unit X. Intercept (a): Y value when X=0. Higher slope = stronger relationship.

questions.question: An R-squared (coefficient of determination) of 0.85 means:

options.A: 85% of data points lie exactly on the regression line
options.B: 85% of the variation in Y is explained by the variation in X
options.D: There is an 85% probability the prediction is correct

questions.explanation: R-squared represents the proportion of variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable(s). An R² of 0.85 means 85% of Y's variation is explained by X.
questions.tip: R² ranges from 0 to 1. Higher = better fit. R² = r² (correlation coefficient squared) in simple regression.

questions.question: A high correlation between two variables:

options.A: Proves that one variable causes the other
options.B: Indicates an association but does not prove causation
options.D: Is only valid if R-squared exceeds 1.0

questions.explanation: Correlation measures the strength and direction of a relationship between variables, but does not prove causation. High correlation could be due to a third variable, coincidence, or true causation.
questions.tip: Correlation ≠ Causation. To establish causation: Need controlled experiments, time sequence, mechanism, rule out confounders.

questions.question: Stratified random sampling involves:

options.A: Selecting every nth item from a population
options.B: Dividing the population into subgroups and randomly sampling from each
options.C: Sampling items that are conveniently available
options.D: Selecting items based on auditor judgment

questions.explanation: Stratified sampling divides the population into homogeneous subgroups (strata) and takes random samples from each stratum. This ensures all subgroups are represented and can improve precision.
questions.tip: Stratified: Divide into strata, sample each. Systematic: Every nth item. Random: Equal chance. Cluster: Sample entire groups.

questions.question: Supervised machine learning uses:

options.A: Unlabeled data to find hidden patterns
options.B: Labeled data with known outcomes to train predictive models

questions.explanation: Supervised learning uses labeled data (input-output pairs) to train models that can predict outcomes for new data. Examples include classification (spam detection) and regression (price prediction).
questions.tip: Supervised: Labeled data (knows answers). Unsupervised: Unlabeled (finds patterns). Reinforcement: Learns from feedback.

questions.question: Benford's Law states that in naturally occurring data sets, the digit '1' appears as the leading digit approximately:

options.B: 20% of the time

questions.explanation: Benford's Law predicts that '1' appears as the first digit about 30.1% of the time in natural data sets, '2' about 17.6%, and so on decreasing to '9' at 4.6%. Useful for fraud detection.
questions.tip: Benford's: 1=30%, 2=18%, 3=12%... Use to detect fabricated data (people assume equal distribution). Works on naturally occurring data.

questions.question: ETL in data analytics stands for:

options.B: Extract, Transform, Load

questions.explanation: ETL refers to Extract (pull data from sources), Transform (clean, format, and prepare data), and Load (put data into target system like a data warehouse). It's fundamental to data integration.
questions.tip: ETL: Extract from sources → Transform (clean, standardize) → Load to warehouse/analytics platform. Key for data integration.

questions.question: An effective analytics dashboard should:

options.A: Include as much data as possible on one screen
options.B: Focus on key metrics with clear visualization aligned to business objectives
options.C: Use as many different chart types as possible
options.D: Show raw data rather than summaries

questions.explanation: Effective dashboards are focused, showing key metrics that align with business objectives using appropriate visualizations. They should be clear, actionable, and avoid information overload.
questions.tip: Good dashboard: Clear KPIs, appropriate charts, minimal clutter, tells a story. Avoid: Too many metrics, confusing visuals, 3D charts.

questions.question: In hypothesis testing, a p-value of 0.03 (with α = 0.05) indicates:

options.A: Fail to reject the null hypothesis
options.B: Reject the null hypothesis
options.D: The sample size is too small

questions.explanation: If p-value (0.03) < significance level α (0.05), we reject the null hypothesis. The result is statistically significant—there's only a 3% probability of observing this result if the null hypothesis were true.
questions.tip: p-value < α: Reject H₀ (significant). p-value > α: Fail to reject H₀. Lower p-value = stronger evidence against H₀.

questions.question: The components of a time series typically include:

options.B: Mean, median, and mode

questions.explanation: Time series are decomposed into: Trend (long-term direction), Seasonality (regular patterns within a year), Cyclical (longer economic cycles), and Irregular/Random (unpredictable fluctuations).
questions.tip: Time series: Trend (up/down), Seasonal (repeating yearly), Cyclical (business cycles), Random (noise). Decomposition helps forecasting.

questions.question: Data governance primarily addresses:

options.B: Policies, procedures, and standards for managing data as an asset

questions.explanation: Data governance establishes policies, procedures, roles, and standards for managing data quality, security, privacy, and compliance. It ensures data is treated as a valuable organizational asset.
questions.tip: Data governance: Who can access data, data quality standards, retention policies, compliance. Key for analytics reliability.

questions.question: Robotic Process Automation (RPA) is best suited for:

options.A: Tasks requiring complex judgment and creativity
options.B: High-volume, rule-based, repetitive tasks

questions.explanation: RPA automates repetitive, rule-based tasks like data entry, reconciliations, and report generation. It follows predefined rules and works best for structured, predictable processes.
questions.tip: RPA best for: Rule-based, repetitive, high-volume, structured data tasks. Not for: Judgment, creativity, unstructured problems.

questions.question: When analyzing data, outliers should typically be:

options.B: Always included regardless of impact
options.C: Investigated to determine if they are errors or valid extreme values

questions.explanation: Outliers should be investigated—they may be data errors (requiring correction/removal) or valid extreme values (potentially important insights). Automatic removal without investigation can lead to poor analysis.
questions.tip: Outliers: Investigate first. Error → correct/remove. Valid → consider impact, possibly use robust statistics or separate analysis.

questions.question: A 3-period moving average forecast for the next period, given the last three periods' sales of 100, 110, and 120, would be:
questions.explanation: Moving average = Sum of periods / Number of periods = (100 + 110 + 120) / 3 = 330 / 3 = 110. This becomes the forecast for the next period.
questions.tip: Moving average: Simple smoothing technique. Weights all periods equally. More periods = smoother (slower response to changes).

questions.question: Data normalization is performed to:

options.B: Scale variables to a common range for comparison

questions.explanation: Normalization scales data to a common range (e.g., 0-1 or z-scores), enabling fair comparison across variables with different units or scales. Important for many machine learning algorithms.
questions.tip: Normalization methods: Min-max (0-1), Z-score (mean=0, SD=1). Required when variables have different scales.

questions.question: In management accounting, total sales variance can be decomposed into:

options.B: Price variance and volume variance

questions.explanation: Total sales variance = Price variance (actual vs. budgeted price × actual quantity) + Volume variance (actual vs. budgeted quantity × budgeted price). This breakdown identifies whether price or volume caused the variance.
questions.tip: Sales variance = Price variance + Volume variance. Similar decomposition for materials: Price + Usage. For labor: Rate + Efficiency.

questions.question: Sentiment analysis is a text analytics technique used to:

options.B: Determine the emotional tone or opinion expressed in text

questions.explanation: Sentiment analysis uses natural language processing to identify and classify the emotional tone (positive, negative, neutral) or opinions expressed in text data like reviews, social media, or survey responses.
questions.tip: Sentiment analysis: Extract opinions from text. Used for: Customer feedback, social media monitoring, brand perception.

questions.question: The '3 Vs' commonly used to describe big data are:

options.B: Volume, Velocity, Variety

questions.explanation: Big data is characterized by Volume (large amounts), Velocity (high speed of generation/processing), and Variety (diverse types and sources). Some add Veracity (uncertainty) and Value as additional Vs.
questions.tip: 3 Vs: Volume (size), Velocity (speed), Variety (types). Extended: Veracity (quality/uncertainty), Value (business worth).

questions.question: Cluster analysis in data mining is used to:

options.B: Group similar records together based on characteristics

questions.explanation: Clustering groups similar data points together without predefined labels. It identifies natural groupings in data and is useful for customer segmentation, anomaly detection, and pattern recognition.
questions.tip: Clustering: Unsupervised (no labels). Groups similar items. Uses: Customer segmentation, anomaly detection, document grouping.

questions.question: Continuous auditing and continuous monitoring differ in that:

options.B: Continuous auditing is performed by management; continuous monitoring by auditors
options.C: Continuous monitoring is performed by management; continuous auditing by auditors

questions.explanation: Continuous monitoring is performed by management to monitor controls and operations. Continuous auditing is performed by internal or external auditors to provide assurance on an ongoing basis.
questions.tip: Monitoring: Management responsibility (first line). Auditing: Auditor responsibility (third line). Both use automated tools.

questions.question: In multiple regression, multicollinearity refers to:

options.A: The dependent variable being highly correlated with error terms
options.B: High correlation among independent variables

questions.explanation: Multicollinearity occurs when independent variables are highly correlated with each other, making it difficult to isolate each variable's effect on the dependent variable. It inflates standard errors and can make coefficients unreliable.
questions.tip: Multicollinearity: Independent variables correlated. Detect with VIF (>10 is concerning). Solutions: Remove variables, combine, use regularization.

questions.question: Overfitting in a predictive model means:

options.A: The model is too simple to capture patterns
options.B: The model performs well on training data but poorly on new data
options.C: The model has too few variables
options.D: The training data set is too large

questions.explanation: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including noise, and fails to generalize to new data. It results in excellent training performance but poor predictive performance on unseen data.
questions.tip: Overfitting: Model memorizes training data. Prevent with: Cross-validation, regularization, simpler models, more training data.

questions.question: In a confusion matrix, precision is calculated as:

options.B: True Positives / (True Positives + False Positives)

questions.explanation: Precision = TP / (TP + FP)—the proportion of positive predictions that are actually correct. It answers: 'Of all items predicted positive, how many are truly positive?' Recall (Sensitivity) = TP / (TP + FN).
questions.tip: Precision: TP/(TP+FP) = correct positive predictions. Recall: TP/(TP+FN) = catching all positives. F1 = harmonic mean of both.

questions.question: Deep learning neural networks differ from traditional machine learning because they:

options.B: Automatically learn features from raw data without manual feature engineering
options.C: Are simpler and faster to train
options.D: Do not require any training data

questions.explanation: Deep learning models (multiple-layer neural networks) automatically learn hierarchical feature representations from raw data. Traditional ML often requires manual feature engineering. Deep learning excels at unstructured data (images, text, audio).
questions.tip: Deep learning: Automatic feature extraction, multiple layers. Best for: Images, speech, text. Requires: Large data, computational power.

questions.question: A key characteristic of blockchain technology for financial applications is:

options.A: Transactions can be easily modified or deleted
options.B: Centralized control by a single authority
options.C: Immutable, distributed ledger providing transparency and traceability

questions.explanation: Blockchain provides an immutable (tamper-resistant), distributed ledger where transactions are transparent, traceable, and verified by network consensus. This is valuable for financial applications requiring trust and audit trails.
questions.tip: Blockchain: Distributed, immutable, transparent. Uses: Cryptocurrency, smart contracts, supply chain, audit trails.

questions.question: Using simple exponential smoothing with α = 0.3, if the previous forecast was 100 and actual demand was 120, the new forecast is:
questions.explanation: Exponential smoothing: New forecast = α(Actual) + (1-α)(Previous forecast) = 0.3(120) + 0.7(100) = 36 + 70 = 106.
questions.tip: Exponential smoothing: F(t) = α×Actual + (1-α)×Previous forecast. Higher α = more weight on recent data. Good for stable data.

questions.question: Algorithmic bias in AI/ML models used for business decisions is primarily caused by:

options.B: Biased training data or biased model design

questions.explanation: Algorithmic bias often originates from biased training data (historical discrimination reflected in data) or biased model design (features that proxy for protected characteristics). This can perpetuate or amplify existing biases.
questions.tip: AI bias sources: Training data, feature selection, model design, evaluation metrics. Important for: Lending, hiring, criminal justice applications.

questions.question: An advantage of decision tree models compared to neural networks is:

options.A: Decision trees always have higher accuracy
options.B: Decision trees are more interpretable and explainable
options.C: Decision trees require more training data
options.D: Decision trees can only handle numerical data

questions.explanation: Decision trees are 'white box' models—you can see and explain the rules used for predictions. Neural networks are 'black boxes' with less interpretable internal workings. This interpretability is important for regulated industries.
questions.tip: Decision trees: Interpretable, handles mixed data, fast. Limitations: Prone to overfitting, unstable. Ensembles (Random Forest) improve accuracy.

questions.question: Monte Carlo simulation in financial analysis:

options.A: Uses deterministic formulas to calculate exact outcomes
options.B: Generates probability distributions by running thousands of scenarios with random inputs
options.C: Is only useful for simple two-variable problems

questions.explanation: Monte Carlo simulation uses random sampling from probability distributions for input variables to generate thousands of possible outcomes. This produces a probability distribution of results, capturing uncertainty and risk.
questions.tip: Monte Carlo: Random sampling, many iterations. Output: Distribution of outcomes. Uses: Risk analysis, option pricing, forecasting with uncertainty.
